bonuses.leadin: When this function for a system is explicitly dependent on time, the system’s behavior is said to be non-autonomous. For 10 points each:

Non-autonomous systems also generally lack this property of having a full set of constants of motion. Solvable systems – systems whose motion has a closed form – have this property, though the converse does not hold.

Computing this quantity, symbolized f, is the usual objective of a scattering problem. It gives the probability density of the outgoing wave as a function of angle, so its square modulus is the differential scattering cross-section.

To do this iterative technique for a scattering problem, insert the incident wave as the wave function in the scattering integral, then re-insert the resulting wave function, etc. This technique gives a first-order scattering amplitude proportional to the integral over all space of the potential times e to the quantity i delta k dot r.

parts: In “On Denoting,” Bertrand Russell argued that names function as disguised versions of what expressions, whose denotational content uniquely identifies an individual?

This philosopher attempted to fix problems in Russell’s theory by suggesting that names correspond to a “cluster” of definite descriptions. He is better known for formulating the Chinese Room thought experiment.

In his article “Reference and Definite Descriptions,” this philosopher used the example of the phrase “Smith’s murderer,” alluding to a man falsely accused of murdering Smith, to illustrate the difference between attributive and referential uses of definite descriptions.

bonuses.leadin: Some Omar Khayyam verses in this form declare that “Wilderness were Paradise enow” if he had “A Book of Verses underneath the Bough, / A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread—and Thou.” For 10 points each:
answers: Sa’di [or Abū-Muhammad Muslih al-Dīn bin Abdallāh Shīrāzī, Saadi Shirazi; prompt on Shirazi]
parts: Give this Persian term for a quatrain, often with an AABA rhyme scheme.

During the 19th century, Goethe (“GURR-tuh”) popularized these Persian and Arabic odes in Europe. Most of the poems in Hafez’s Divan are in this form, written in couplets whose second line ends with a refrain called a radif.
Although this 13th-century Persian poet wrote many ghazals, he is better known for the aphorisms collected in his Gulistan and the didactic verse tales collected in his Bustan.

bonuses.leadin: Implements used in this ritual included a snake-shaped blade called a werhekau and a forked blade called a peseshkaf that was also used to cut umbilical cords. For 10 points each:
answers: the Opening of the Mouth and Eyes (ceremony or ritual) [or wepet-er]
parts: Name this ritual, legendarily invented by Ptah, that was performed both to restore certain people's access to sustenance and light and to allow statues to act as surrogate bodies.
One of the priests carrying out the Opening of the Mouth ceremony wore a jackal mask to impersonate this Egyptian god of death and mummification.

Anubis also oversaw the weighing of the hearts of the dead against the feather of Ma'at; hearts that failed the test were immediately eaten by this demoness, who was part-lion, part-crocodile, and part-hippo.

bonuses.leadin: Complexes with this property are found on the right-hand side of Tanabe-Sugano diagrams. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of complex that typically contains strong-field ligands.
In coordination complexes, ligands cause a splitting in the energy of these sets of five orbitals, which are partially occupied in transition metals.
Complexes containing 8 d-electrons in low-spin environments tend to form complexes with this geometry. This geometry’s highest-energy d-orbital is the dx2-y2 (“d x squared minus y squared”) orbital.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the story “Mr. Miao” from Pu Songling’s Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio, for 10 points each.
answers: The Library of Babel [or La biblioteca de Babel]
parts: The title character of Mr. Miao can transform into this animal. Other literary examples of this animal are Shere Khan from The Jungle Book and Richard Parker, who accompanies the protagonist on a lifeboat in The Life of Pi.
“Mr Miao” was one of the stories Jorge Luis Borges chose for a real-life anthology of this title. A Borges story with this title imagines a place that collects every possible combination of letters.

“Mr Miao” was re-titled “The Tiger Guest” in this sinologist’s 1880 bowdlerized translation of Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio, the earliest in English. He is better known for the transliteration system he introduced in his 1892 Chinese-English dictionary.

bonuses.leadin: Henry Garnet wrote treatises advocating that these people use tricks like “mental reservation” and “equivocation” to avoid lying when interrogated. For 10 points each:
answers: Catholic priests [or Jesuits; prompt on Catholics, synonyms for clerics, saints, or martyrs; prompt on priests with “of what denomination?”]
Anne [or Anna; accept Anne Vaux or Anne of Denmark (the wife of James I)]
parts: Name these people, such as Edmund Campion, who were the target of a campaign of persecution begun in the 1580s. Nicholas Owen built many hiding places for these people, their namesake “holes,” in country manors.
The Jesuit Henry Garnet was executed for being the confessor of Robert Catesby, the leader of this failed plot that would have installed James I’s daughter Elizabeth as a Catholic queen.

A wealthy Catholic recusant of the Vaux (“vox”) family with this first name used orange juice to write letters to Henry Garnet during his imprisonment. The North Berwick witch trials were held after a fleet bringing a queen with this first name from Denmark was nearly wrecked by storms.

bonuses.leadin: A paper by Karolyi et al. attempted to use chaos theory to resolve a paradox about these organisms, which asks why they often co-exist in the same niche in violation of the competitive exclusion principle. For 10 points each:
answers: plankton [accept the paradox of the plankton]
hadal zone [or the hadopelagic zone; do NOT prompt on “hadean”]
parts: Name this type of organism that is the subject of a paradox devised by G. Evelyn Hutchinson. Photosynthetic species of this type of organism produce the carbon in the biological pump.

Another solution to the paradox of the plankton involves dividing up the pelagic region into five zones, and treating them each as their own ecosystem. Heterotrophs in this deepest layer of the pelagic zone eat marine snow and occupy trenches below the benthos.

When plankton move from the pelagic to the littoral zone, they may cause a “tide” named for this color, in which algae bloom and poison the waters. These “tides” are responsible for several adverse effects, such as the accumulation of saxitoxin in shellfish.

bonuses.leadin: Leonard Bernstein loved the limelight, but sometimes he had to share it with soloists. For 10 points each:
parts: A 14-year-old Midori (“mih-daw-ree”) snapped E strings on two different violins while playing Bernstein’s Serenade with this orchestra during their regular summer residence at Tanglewood.

Before accompanying this eccentric Canadian pianist in Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1, Bernstein infamously disavowed the performance. This pianist was known for his detached articulation in performances of Bach.

Bernstein went on to record both of Brahms’s piano concerti and Beethoven’s last three piano concerti with this Polish pianist. This pianist formed the Polish Festival Orchestra with whom he recorded a hyper-detailed set of Chopin concerti.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about sumptuary laws passed to regulate fashion in colonial America, for 10 points each.
answers: beaver [prompt on fur, pelts, or skins]
governor of Spanish Louisiana [do not accept answers mentioning “French Louisiana” or “New France”] (the first governor is Esteban Rodríguez Miró)
parts: In 1621, this colony restricted the wearing of high fashion to members of its Governor’s Council. The lower part of this colony’s legislature was the House of Burgesses.

A 1634 ordinance in the Massachusetts Bay Colony forbade, among other things, the wearing of silk, gold thread, and hats made of this material. This commodity names the wars the Iroquois fought against Algonquian tribes in the 18th century.

A holder of this title passed a law forcing Black women to wear tignon headscarves. “Bloody” O’Reilly also held this title, as did a man who settled Canarian migrants called isleños in his namesake Galvez Town.

bonuses.leadin: Alexander Cold and his grandmother join an Amazon expedition in this author’s novel City of the Beasts. For 10 points each:
answers: Isabel Allende [or Isabel Angélica Allende Llona]
staying silent [accept clear equivalents, such as silence or being mute or not talking]
parts: Name this Chilean author who wrote about the Trueba family in her debut novel, The House of the Spirits.
The Trueba family seek medical help when Clara chooses to engage in this behavior for nine years, stopping at last on her nineteenth birthday.

This character tells such tales as “Toad's Mouth” and “The Little Heidelberg” in a collection by Allende. She is also the title character of a novel in which she has a romance with the guerrilla fighter Huberto Naranjo.

bonuses.leadin: Natalie Zemon Davis is currently working on a book about David Nassy, one of the leaders of a slave-holding Jewish community in this colony. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this colony where “Jew’s Savannah” was founded. Abolitionists spread John Gabriel Stedman’s illustrations of slavery in this colony, which stayed in the hands of one imperial power via the 1667 Treaty of Breda.

These people, who formed groups like the Kwinti and Ndyuka in Suriname, often timed their raids against Jodensavanne to coincide with Yom Kippur. In general, this term refers to slaves who escaped and established free colonies in places like Jamaica.
The plantations at Jodensavanne produced this good from its namesake “cane,” and struggled to turn a profit after cultivation of its namesake “beet” became popular in Europe.

bonuses.leadin: In a play, the arrival of a member of this profession is re-enacted in “The Dance of the Lost Traveller.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this profession. The protagonist recounts switching identities with Robert Zwelinzima’s corpse in a play that begins and ends in the workplace of a member of this profession.
The first of those plays is this one by Wole Soyinka. This play’s title characters are the chieftain Baroka and the town beauty Sidi, who is sought after by the Westernizing schoolteacher Lakunle.
The second aforementioned play is Sizwe Bansi is Dead by Athol Fugard, an author from this country, whose Nobel Laureates include J.M. Coetzee.

bonuses.leadin: This man built on the work of Robert Floyd to develop a set of rules used to determine the correctness of computer programs in the field of formal methods. For 10 points each:
answers: Sir Anthony Hoare [or Charles Richard Tony Hoare]
null pointer [or null value point; prompt on dangling pointer]
parts: Name this computer scientist, the 1980 Turing Award laureate. He also invented the language CSP.
In 2009, Hoare apologized for inventing pointers that have this property, calling it a “billion dollar mistake.” In C++, dereferencing this kind of pointer will lead to undefined behavior.

Hoare also recast Dijkstra’s [DYKE-struh’s] formulation of the dining philosophers problem to more intuitively show how this situation may appear, in which a concurrent system is unable to do any more work since every agent is awaiting progress from others.

bonuses.leadin: Because it was written for Pentecost, this piece includes a setting of the Veni Sancte Spiritus and two Alleluias. For 10 points each:
answers: Short Ride in a Fast Machine
parts: Name this choral work in the tintinnabuli (“tin-tin-AAB-yoo-lee”) style, which was originally written for choir and organ, but is frequently performed in a 1997 version accompanied by string orchestra.

The Berliner Messe is by Arvo Pärt (“pairt”), whose style is sometimes called the “holy” variant of this style, associated with Philip Glass. It makes use of limited musical material, which is frequently repeated.
There is disagreement as to whether this “fanfare for orchestra” by John Adams should count as a work of minimalism or postminimalism. It begins with a pulse for woodblock.

bonuses.leadin: Transitions whose symmetries match x, y, or z on a character table are detectable by this technique. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this analytical technique which detects transitions that cause a change in a molecule’s dipole moment.
A stretch at about 1750 cm-1 (“inverse centimeters”) in IR spectroscopy indicates the stretching mode of one of these functional groups consisting of a carbon double bonded to an oxygen.

The number of vibrational modes for a non-linear molecule with N atoms is this function of N, which can be found by taking the total number of degrees of freedom for each atom then subtracting translational and rotational degrees of freedom.

bonuses.leadin: Some 18th-century European poets dabbled in epic poetry. For 10 points each:
answers: da Gama [accept Basilio da Gama or Vasco da Gama]
Hermann and Dorothea [or Hermann und Dorothea]
parts: This French author wrote the mock epic The Maid of Orleans and the actual epic La Henriade (“lah awn-ree-ah-duh”). You may know him better for writing Candide.

An 18th-century poet with this surname wrote of the subjugation of the Guarani people by the Jesuits in the epic O Uraguai. A real-life historical figure with this last name is the protagonist of The Lusiads.
Goethe’s (“GURR-tuhz”) only foray into epic poetry was this work about the romance between an innkeeper’s son and a refugee from the French Revolutionary Wars.

bonuses.leadin: Lesser divinities worshipped alongside these gods included gods of fortune called bagha and angel-like beings called yazata. For 10 points each:
answers: the ahuras [do not accept or prompt on “asuras”]
Zoroastrianism [or Behdin Mazdayasna; prompt on Mazdayasna]
parts: Name these deities from ancient Iranian religion, who were opposed to the daevas. They correspond to a set of cognate deities who were the antagonists of the Vedic gods in ancient Indian religion.
The most prominent of the ahuras, Ahura Mazda, became the supreme god of this dualistic Persian religion. In this religion, the daevas are the servants of the evil god Angra Mainyu.

Another important ancient Iranian deity, along with Mithra and Ahura Mazda, was this water goddess whose cult was absorbed into Zoroastrianism. This goddess shared several characteristics of Ishtar and Saraswati.

bonuses.leadin: Robert K. Merton’s strain theory suggested that this sort of behavior can be produced by societal pressure to conform. For 10 points each:
answers: Outsiders: Studies in the Sociology of Deviance
control theory [accept power-control theory; accept social control theory]
parts: Give this term in sociology and criminology for behavior that departs from or breaks societal norms.
Sociologist Howard S. Becker pioneered labeling theory in this 1963 book that argues that deviance is a socially constructed phenomenon

This word follows “power” in a theory by John Hagan that identifies differing parental restrictions as the cause of the gender gap in deviance. This word follows “social” in a Travis Hirschi theory that says that ties to institutions like family prevent one from acting out.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about East Asian fox spirit myths, for 10 points each.
parts: In Japan, pure-white foxes serve as the messengers of this Shinto kami of fertility, sake, and rice, whose foremost shrine is in the Fushimi ward of Kyoto.

In a Chinese myth, this favorite concubine of King Zhou was possessed by a malevolent nine-tailed fox spirit who served Nüwa. Her influence over King Zhou eventually led to the rebellion that ended the Shang Dynasty.
Fox spirits called gumiho are almost always depicted as malevolent in later legends from this peninsula, whose myths also include hanbok-wearing spirits called dokkaebi (doh-kay-bee).

bonuses.leadin: Maurice Ravel (“ruh-vell”) often took inspiration from other composers. For 10 points each:
answers: Valses nobles et sentimentales [accept in either order; or noble and sentimental]
“Åse’s Death” from Peer Gynt [or “The Death of Åse” or “Åses død”]
parts: Ravel was inspired by Schubert’s waltzes to write a set of waltzes titled for these two adjectives.
Ravel’s string quartet took this other French composer’s string quartet as its model. Ravel also made a four-hands transcription of his Prélude to the Afternoon of a Faun.

A lost early work by Ravel was his Variations on a Theme of Grieg, which was based on this slow movement by Grieg that begins with the ascending notes F-sharp, B, C-sharp in a quarter-quarter-half note rhythm.
